title: SoCal R Users Group (SoCal RUG): Advent of Code 2021 Event 1  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
The Advent of Code (https://adventofcode.com), a series of daily programming puzzles that starts on December 1 and runs up to Christmas. We will meet every Monday, during this period, where we will discuss different approaches to tackling (and hopefully solving) the challenges using R and related languages/tools. This is a good opportunity for R newbies to familiarise themselves with the basics of programming syntax, as well as for advanced users to learn tips and tricks.

We also have a private leaderboard that you can join with code[masked]cdd2ba. We will be offering prizes from the AoC Shop (https://advent-of-code.creator-spring.com/) for the top three positions on the leaderboard (US residents only; you must have an AoC account).

title: CaRdiff - the Cardiff R User Group: Winter Tidy Thursday ‚ùÖ‚ùÖ‚ùÖ  [Virtual] , United Kingdom, Europe
group: CaRdiff - the Cardiff R User Group
description:
Come join us for this next Winter edition of Tidy Thursday.

Tidy Tuesdays are weekly R projects on 'tidying' data, associated (but not exclusive!) to the 'tidyverse': ggplot2, dplyr, tidyr and friends.

You can find out more about Tidy Tuesdays here: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday

We will meet (on Thursday!), find the most recent data set and 'tidy' it up together.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
This week's dataset is on ...

Spice Girls!

https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2021/2021-12-14

Get yourself into the mood:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gJLIiF15wjQ

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

This session will be beginner-friendly, hands-on, and potentially pair programming driven.

Learning outcomes: Data Preparation, Data Munging, Tidy Data, Tidyverse

It would be helpful for attendees to have the following already installed, but if you run into trouble we can help on the day.

* R: https://www.r-project.org/
* R Studio desktop: https://rstudio.com/products/rstudio/
* Tidyverse: https://www.tidyverse.org/

These are all free tools, and install will take roughly 20-40 min depending on hardware and internet speeds.

Our previous work is available here:
https://github.com/CaRdiffR/tidy_thursdays

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group, United States, US/Canada
description:
Until we can meet again in person, please join our Slack workspace to stay in touch, ask questions, and share information throughout the week.

https://join.slack.com/t/centraliowarusergroup/shared_invite/zt-dhfa5ude-0tvHascxRkn2pgiqDdQgrw

The Slack workspace is available any time, not just Saturday mornings.

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: NottinghamR - Nottingham R Users Group: How to make an R package: A Beginner's Guide, United Kingdom, Europe
R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjast√≥w R): Why R? Webinar: Recent developments of Joint Models using R, Poland, Europe
group: R Users & R-Ladies Warsaw (Spotkania Entuzjast√≥w R)
description:
WhyR? Webinars are back !

Webinar: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eC1-B2RLGwk

Title:
Recent developments of Joint Models for longitudinal and survival data using R

Abstract:

Many biomedical follow-up studies aim to investigate the relationship between a repeated measurement, measured with error and time-to-event data. Joint modelling approaches are used to study these two types of data simultaneously to assess the effect of longitudinal biomarkers on time-to-event data. The first joint modelling proposals have been based on a relationship between one single longitudinal biomarker and time-to-event data. Recently, several extensions have been developed for multivariate longitudinal and survival data, for non-linear longitudinal and survival data, to use different association structures between the longitudinal biomarker and patients` survival and for personalized dynamic predictions of time-to-event data. In this talk, we will focus on the recent developments of joint models from both frequentist and Bayesian perspective, with developed R packages.

Speaker: Ipek Guler

I am Ipek Guler born in Turkey in 1986, after finishing my University degree in Gazi University, Ankara, I have started to my master degree in University of Santiago de Compostela, Spain where I have specialized in applied statistical techniques. During my master studies, I had different internships in Clinical Hospital of Santiago de Compostela, IDICHUS and a spin-off company and I focused my research on longitudinal and survival data.

I have worked in several research projects as a researcher in biostatistics group of University of Santiago de Compostela during 6 years, as a statistical consultant in Maimonides Biomedical Research Institute of C√≥rdoba (IMIBIC) for 2 years and also have worked in national Covid registry data with the Spanish Internal Medicine Society (SEMI). I am currently working in Leuven Biostatistics and Statistical Bioinformatics Centre (L-BioStat) KU Leuven.

description:
Exploratory Data Analysis with:
> {dataExplorer}
> {chronicle}
> {esquisse}
> and more.
> Presented by Priyanka Gagneja

With a plethora of packages that can help us with exploratory data analysis (EDA), it can be difficult to know where to start! Some packages are specific for a given data type, while others are more general.

In this talk, Priyanka Gagneja (github.com/priyankagagneja ) will walk us through her EDA workflow and share a few of her favorite packages in doing so.

Speaker Bio:
Priyanka Gagneja is a Data Scientist/Freelance Analytics Professional. Priyanka graduated from Boston College with a Masters in Applied Economics and holds an MBA and Bachelor's in Computer Science from India. She has experience providing supply chain-related solutions to retail clients.

title: CopenhagenR - useR Group: Three Strategies to Tackle Big Data in R - !Now Online only!  [Virtual] , Denmark, Europe
description:
** Update: This live event has been canceled due to the current Covid situation in CHP . A downscaled online presentation will still be happening at 13:00 December 14, which you are welcome to join**

Speaker: Rasmus B√•√•th
Date: December 14, 2021
Time: 1pm - 1:45pm CET
Location: Now online using zoom

ABSTRACT

Big data might not be the buzzword it was five years ago, but it's more prevalent than ever. Even if you aren't currently dealing with big data, chances are that sooner or later you'll find yourself with a dataset that is just too big for your normal R setup to handle.

At this meetup in collaboration with CopenhagenR, Rasmus B√•√•th, data science lead at Castle.io, will share three strategies that can be used to tackle big data in R (and python if that's your cup of tea). Three big data tools will be briefly introduced: duckDB, Spark and SnowflakeDB.

The CopenhagenR meetup is ramping up again and invites you to join this event aimed at everybody working with or interested in data science.

ABOUT THE SPEAKERS

Rasmus B√•√•th - Rasmus is a data science lead at Castle.io, a Y combinator-backed startup building an AI-based security and fraud detection service. He's worked with big data in many different forms and knows that, while it can be a pain to handle big data, there can be great business value (and good career opportunities) knowing how to do so.

title: Montreal R User Group: Data Reliability Engineering Conference (DRE-CON)  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:

Data has become a core competitive advantage for modern organizations ‚Äî making data reliability more important than ever. Driven by this growing need, the tools, techniques, and best practices for keeping data fresh, accurate, reliable, and trustworthy are rapidly evolving ‚Äî changing the game up and down the entire data stack. To unlock the full potential of their organization‚Äôs data, every data team needs to take an engineering approach to data reliability.

Join us on December 14 for the first Data Reliability Engineering Conference: 14+ sessions from data engineering teams, modern data stack companies, and founders from Figma, Netflix, Wayfair, Preset, Looker, Rockset, Great Expectations, Netflix, Wayfair, Figma, Tecton, Alation, and more. Learn how they are solving complex data reliability issues at their organizations.

Topics include:
-How the Modern Data Stack is Reshaping Data Engineering
-Controlling Changes at the Source - Treating Data as Code
-Achieving Speed at Scale: the Modern Real-time Data Stack
-Monitoring: A Data Science Perspective
-Simplicity at Scale - Promoting Reuse and Reliability of Data Across Distributed Data Organizations
-Setting Standards to Ensure Analytics Users‚Äô Trust

title: Cleveland R User Group: Andres Rodriguez: Gravity Model of European Soccer Player Transfers  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Gravity Model of European Soccer Player Transfers

Newton's law of universal gravitation was stated in the 17th century as "every particle attracts every other particle in the universe with a force that is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the distance between their centers." This law was then the inspiration of Jan Tinbergen's work on Econometric Gravity Models of International Trade in the 20th century.

I will demonstrate how the work of Newton and Tinbergen inspired me to create a model of Soccer Player Transfers in European Soccer using:

* rvest to web scrape
* ggmap and Google Cloud Platform to geocode addresses
* geosphere to calculate latitude and longitude distance

Hope to see you there.

Andres Rodriguez has been an avid R User for 5 years now and currently works as a Data Analyst in Progressive Insurance's Commercial Lines division. He is passionate about using R to create soccer data analyses which can be seen at his blog socceranalyticsfc.com

Note: this talk will be recorded and posted on our YouTube channel.

title: Wellington R Users Group (WRUG): Masterclass: R for data visualisation (and reporting)  [Virtual] , New Zealand, Australia
description:
Whether you are a beginner or are needing a refresh, you can join this training to gain familiarity with the statistical programming language R and learn how to take your data and reporting to the next level.

We have developed this intro level training to give people a leg up to get started toward reporting and dashboards in R - we would appreciate if you could share with potentially interested colleagues outside of the group. Hope to see some of you there, too!

ABOUT THIS EVENT:
Have you got lots of ideas of what you want to do with your data but just can‚Äôt get there yet? Over 5 sessions we will look into the basics of the statistical programming language R and how it can be applied to data visualisation and automated report generation. We cover data cleaning and pre-processing, transforming your data, displaying it in multiple formats (data table and plots), and finally tying it all together in a R Markdown file that you can save and share with your audience. We will work through multiple datasets and exercises so on conclusion of the class you can hit the ground running.

WHO SHOULD ATTEND:
You are new to R or feel a bit rusty with your R skills and have a keen interest in furthering your ability to manage, display and share data. Maybe you have been mainly using Excel or an off-the shelf tool like Power BI, but are frustrated by its limitations and are keen to build more advanced visuals to do your data justice. You might have a dataset or model you want to prepare outputs for and want to progress to a more powerful, efficient and streamlined process. This Masterclass can be used as an entry into R or can be used as preparation for our R Shiny Masterclasses.

INSTRUCTORS:
Dr. Uli Muellner (Director ‚Äî IT & Information Design)
Crystal Johnston (Full-Stack Developer)
Nick Snellgrove (Full-Stack Developer)

FORMAT:
5 interactive online sessions; supported by dedicated online learning plattform for asynchronous learning and interaction.

COST
$985 NZD (excl. GST)

Learn more and register at www.epi-interactive.com/events/r-for-data-visualisation

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: Pins - where have you been all my life?  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our December Meetup (last of 2021!) will be a remote gathering; the Zoom link will be posted the week of the event.

Like that one piece of furniture in your living room that you need, but you just can‚Äôt find a spot for, we often struggle to find a home for the mid‚Äêprocess artifacts of a data analysis.
Think about some of your workflows. Are you:
‚Ä¢ Using read_csv() to bring in emailed data?
‚Ä¢ Saving .Rds or .RData objects to be called later?
‚Ä¢ Sharing your model or data across multiple apps?
‚Ä¢ Redeploying your app every time the supporting data is updated?
A ‚Äúyes‚Äù to any of the above indicates a solid use case for pins. Pins were developed to make discovering, caching, and sharing resources simpler. Learn how to get started with this gem of a package and how it can help promote more efficient workflows.

Katie Masiello got her start in R doing statistical and risk analysis in the aerospace industry. Since joining RStudio in 2019, she has worked with RStudio‚Äôs enterprise customers to demonstrate and build value in their analytics using RStudio‚Äôs suite of professional and open source tools. She works with teams across a full spectrum - those just beginning their journey with data science to those fully entrenched in high-value production deployments - to share best practices, teach more efficient workflows, and empower teams to shine.

title: Oslo useR! Group: Wrapping Packages in R with {devtools} and Friends  [Virtual] , Norway, Europe
description:
[Abstract]
For this year's final meetup, we'll be wrapping a holiday season-themed package! Using {devtools} and all its little helpers, like {usethis} and {testthat}, we'll walk through the basic process of making a package, and will address some of the most common best practices and dos-and-donts.

Afterwards, we'll recap the past year and want to hear from you - the community - about topics and speakers you want to see and hear next year.

Don't forget to bring your gl√∏gg and some pepperkake :)

[Bios]
Raoul Wolf is a senior environmental advisor and scientific developer at the Norwegian Geotechnical Institute (www.ngi.no). He has experience in using R from research to production, and occasionally teaches R. He's also well-trained in drinking gl√∏gg and eating pepperkake.

title: Saint Louis R User Group: KNIME Workflows for Citizen Data Science  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
By: Jay Harrison

KNIME is a free, open-source platform for data science. KNIME users construct workflows by joining nodes, or icons representing specific functions, in a logical sequence. This low-code approach is attractive for people who want perform data analysis tasks without learning a programming language. KNIME is not a comprehensive solution, but R code can be incorporated and executed to fill in the gaps. We will demonstrate KNIME and describe its use in a citizen data scientist program.

Scott Fincher and Cynthia Padilla from KNIME will also be joining us. They will answer the technical and business-related questions that people may have.

title: R-Ladies Bari: Virtual Data Science Learnathon: From Raw Data to Deployment Online!  [Virtual] , Italy, Europe
description:
Abbiamo il piacere di annunciare un nuovo meetup in collaborazione con KNIME (knime.com).

Il (Virtual) Learnathon √® un evento a met√† tra un hackathon e un workshop: √® un workshop perch√© si studia il processo di data science. Ma √® anche un hackathon, perch√© si lavora in gruppi, attraverso esercizi, per mettere a punto la soluzione.

Durante il Learnathon sperimenteremo l‚Äôintero ciclo di un progetto di data science dall‚Äôaccesso ai dati fino al deployment, passando per un paio di algoritmi di Machine Learning.

Lo strumento che utilizzeremo √® KNIME Analytics Platform (https://www.knime.com/knime-analytics-platform).
KNIME Analytics Platform √® open ed offre anche un ambiente di sviluppo integrato per R, Python, SQL e Spark.

Dopo un‚Äôintroduzione iniziale ci divideremo in gruppi. Ciascun gruppo si focalizzer√† su uno dei tre aspetti del ciclo del progetto:

Gruppo 1: ETL. Focus sull‚Äôaccesso ai dati e sulla data preparation.
Gruppo 2: Machine Learning. Che modello dovrei usare? Con quali parametri?
Gruppo 3: Deployment. Dopo aver trovato un buon modello, cosa succede? Focus sulla fase di deployment.

Per via della situazione attuale non sar√† possibile incontrarsi di persona. In alternative, tutti potranno scaricare il materiale del workshop qui:

Data scientists esperti saranno a disposizione per consigli e informazioni.

Per partecipare √® necessario portare il proprio laptop con KNIME Analytics Platform preinstallata e il materiale del workshop.

Dopo un‚Äôintroduzione su Zoom mostreremo come spostarci su Gather (info: https://gather.town) per dividerci in gruppi e comunicare informalmente su una mappa interattiva. E‚Äô raccomandato usare Google Chrome una volta su Gather.

title: CalgaryR: Introduction to Shiny App in R  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Please welcome our speaker, David Aponte, PhD Candidate in medical science at the University of Calgary.

Shiny is an R framework for interacting with data through a web app. If you have complex data that is either continuously updated or big enough for people to explore for their own insights, Shiny is a fantastic library for creating visual tools to open up your data to the broader community. Shiny apps can easily be deployed to the web, allowing others to leverage your data and analyses without the fuss of installing anything or writing code.

In this workshop, we will learn the basics of making a Shiny application, starting with how you can take your existing analyses and make them work with user selectable inputs. We‚Äôll also go over some tips for making your Shiny app work efficiently and look slick. Finally, we will go over deploying your Shiny application to a live website for anyone to use.

If you‚Äôd like to follow along with the workshop, make sure to download the Github repository from https://github.com/J0vid/CalgaryR_Shiny The GitHub readme briefly outlines the goals of the workshop, as well as potential future topics.

About the speaker:

David Aponte is a PhD Candidate in medical science at the University of Calgary. His dissertation work has focused on how genetic variation produces facial shape variation in mice and humans. He has used R for a wide array of projects like measuring color patterns from image data and identifying genetic syndromes from measurements of facial shape.

Please join us and learn together.

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: What's New and Upcoming with tidymodels  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
Max Kuhn returns again to tell us about new happenings in tidymodels.

This meetup is the runup to the 2021 Government & Public Sector R Conference and Workshops taking place virtually December 8-10. Members of the group can use code nyhackr for a 20% discount at https://rstats.ai/gov/.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack: https://nyhackr.org/slack.html

About the Talk:
The tidymodels framework is a collection of packages for modeling and machine learning using tidyverse principles. We've been working hard to add new features and fix bugs. I'll talk about censored regression, model deployment, case weights, and other features in progress. Additionally, the results from this year's user poll will be shown.

About Max:
Max Kuhn is a software engineer at RStudio. He is currently working on improving R's modeling capabilities. He was a Senior Director of Nonclinical Statistics at Pfizer Global R&D in Connecticut. He was applying models in the pharmaceutical and diagnostic industries for over 18 years. Max has a Ph.D. in Biostatistics. Max is the author of numerous R packages for techniques in machine learning and reproducible research. He, and Kjell Johnson, wrote the book Applied Predictive Modeling, which won the Ziegel award from the American Statistical Association, which recognizes the best book reviewed in Technometrics in 2015. Their second book, Feature Engineering and Selection, was published in 2019.

The talk will begin at 7 PM America/New_York and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

title: R-Ladies Philly: Building Packages at Work  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
This holiday season, consider treating your coworkers (and yourself!) to an R package - the gift that keeps on giving!

A series of short presentations by Alison Moss, Jess Streeter and Jake Riley on the topic of R package development and maintenance in the workplace.

1)
Alison Moss presents: dataVisEasy - seamless integration of metadata and data for easy and accurate visualizations

After getting tired of running similar lines of code over and over again to make minor adjustments to heatmaps and data visualizations, I accidentally found myself writing several functions to make all that tweaking easier, eventually turning into it into a package. Now seamlessly integrating metadata into data visualizations is nice and easy and all those minor tweaks your boss asks for don‚Äôt have to be an extra source of stress.

Alison just recently graduated with her PhD from Thomas Jefferson University and is now working at Rajant Health Inc as a Computational Biologist. She absolutely loves coding in R and gets way too much enjoyment out of writing and debugging functions to make data analysis and visualizations easy and consistent.

2)
Jess Streeter presents: Nerdify your life

Learn about Spring Health's internal package, Nerdify, and how it has streamlined several internal processes across our growing data team.

Jess is a Senior Data Scientist at Spring Health. She has spent her entire career working on issues around mental health. When she's not coding away, she enjoys spending time with her family, drinking good beer, and training Jiu Jitsu.

3)
Jake Riley presents: rocqi - simplifying workflows & reducing technical debt

Learn about one of CHOP‚Äôs internal R packages, rocqi. We built this package to improve the process for accessing, formatting, and visualizing data. Categories include quick and easy database connections, ggplot themes, Rmd/dashboard templates, internal datasets, and many helper functions for presenting data to stakeholders. In this talk I‚Äôll discuss the types of solutions we chose to tackle and how package development has made us all better programmers.

Jake is a Senior Data Analyst at the Children‚Äôs Hospital of Philadelphia. He works with the Analytics Architecture team to provide centralized solutions for a large team of analysts. His work with rocqi has inspired the development of other R packages including: simplecolors (CRAN), shinyobjects (CRAN), headliner (beta), whereiation (dev), and codereviewr (dev). https://github.com/rjake

Please note: We are limited to 100 attendees, so make sure to join on time if you'd like to participate in the live event. The workshop will be recorded and shared on our YouTube channel shortly after the meetup event.

title: trigeR - Tr√≥jmiejska Grupa Entuzjast√≥w R: WhyR? Webinar: Recent developments of Joint Models using R  [Virtual] , Poland, Europe
description:
WhyR? Webinars are back !

Webinar: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eC1-B2RLGwk

Title:
Recent developments of Joint Models for longitudinal and survival data using R

Abstract:

Many biomedical follow-up studies aim to investigate the relationship between a repeated measurement, measured with error and time-to-event data. Joint modelling approaches are used to study these two types of data simultaneously to assess the effect of longitudinal biomarkers on time-to-event data. The first joint modelling proposals have been based on a relationship between one single longitudinal biomarker and time-to-event data. Recently, several extensions have been developed for multivariate longitudinal and survival data, for non-linear longitudinal and survival data, to use different association structures between the longitudinal biomarker and patients` survival and for personalized dynamic predictions of time-to-event data. In this talk, we will focus on the recent developments of joint models from both frequentist and Bayesian perspective, with developed R packages.

Speaker: Ipek Guler

I am Ipek Guler born in Turkey in 1986, after finishing my University degree in Gazi University, Ankara, I have started to my master degree in University of Santiago de Compostela, Spain where I have specialized in applied statistical techniques. During my master studies, I had different internships in Clinical Hospital of Santiago de Compostela, IDICHUS and a spin-off company and I focused my research on longitudinal and survival data.

I have worked in several research projects as a researcher in biostatistics group of University of Santiago de Compostela during 6 years, as a statistical consultant in Maimonides Biomedical Research Institute of C√≥rdoba (IMIBIC) for 2 years and also have worked in national Covid registry data with the Spanish Internal Medicine Society (SEMI). I am currently working in Leuven Biostatistics and Statistical Bioinformatics Centre (L-BioStat) KU Leuven.

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: Level up your ggplot: How do I add labels, arrows and other annotations?  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
In this workshop, we'll discuss different ways of annotating your plots. For example, we might want to highlight data points that defy the overall trend, or explain what a line or colour within the graph means, or comment on and interpret the plot.
We'll first show you how to manually draw arrows and insert text boxes in your graph. Then, we'll explore the annotation geoms the {ggforce} package offers and recreate the commented Bechdel test graph you can see at the top of the page.

---
It's important to us to ensure that R-Ladies Freiburg events are a safe space for gender minorities and especially those who are just starting out with R. All are welcome at this meetup but we specifically ask cisgender men to take a passive role in this meetup and hold comments/ questions until after others have had the chance to ask. Thank you for your support!

title: BernR: An Introduction to R with the Stanford Heart Transplant data  [Virtual] , Switzerland, Europe
description:
A presentation by Simon Schwab from Swisstransplant, Bern.

The event takes place online. The link to the meeting will be visible for registered participants shortly before the beginning of the event (at the latest).

This is the first session of a new introductory series into R for beginners called "R Fundamentals". This first session gives a brief overview of R and RStudio:
- data types
- exploring data
- some basic statistics
- figures with ggplot2
- R Notebooks

Examples will be from Stanford Heart Transplant dataset from the "survival" package. Slides and materials (R notebook) will be made available before the session at https://osf.io/ex6v7/. Thus, if desired, the audience can interact with the data already during the session.

Future R Fundamentals will cover specific topics in more detail, e.g. data reading & data cleaning, ggplot2, descriptive statistics, etc.

title: R-Ladies Santa Barbara: R-Ladies SB x Central Coast Python: Data Science with R & Python, United States, US/Canada
description:
Mark you calendars for a first-of-its-kind R-Ladies SB x Central Coast Python Meetup on December 15th!

Python can be a powerful alternative/complementary language to R, and while we here at R-Ladies are certainly partial to the latter, adding another language to our data science toolkit is something we are always excited for.

We have collaborated with Central Coast Python to bring you an R to Python (and vice versa) translation workshop, where we will learn to wrangle and visualize the same dataset using both languages.

This event is open to R/Python enthusiasts of all skill levels!

You may choose to follow along on our screens or download the required software and packages to code along on your own machines. If you do not already have R and Python installed, please be sure to do so before the event on December 15th. Find our installation instructions for R/RStudio, Python/Anaconda, and required packages on the event's GitHub README: https://github.com/samanthacsik/RLadiesSB-RvsPython

We will be available to help troubleshoot any setup issues on 12/07 from 5:30-6:30pm via Zoom: https://ucsb.zoom.us/j/81620992244?pwd=d2ZQTCtwZVZvU3Q4M25FN1hIM1Fxdz09.

This will be a hybrid in-person/remote event. We are excited to begin meeting/networking with our communities once again, but understand that not everyone may be comfortable attending events in person still. We will do our best to answer questions for those attending virtually, but please understand that we may be slow to respond as we navigate our first hybrid event.

PLEASE NOTE: Masks are required for in-person attendance and vaccination status will be verified at the door.

DIRECTIONS: This event will be held at the National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis (NCEAS) at 1021 Anacapa St. Our offices conveniently sit at SB city lot #8. The first 75min of parking are free and $1.50 per hour after that. Street parking is also available on the surrounding streets. Please enter the first floor office space through the side door that faces the parking lot (located on the left side of the building, if your back is to Anacapa St.).

REMOTE ATTENDEES: Please join the event via Zoom https://ucsb.zoom.us/j/82671745133

Banner Image Source: https://towardsdatascience.com/is-python-faster-than-r-db06c5be5ce8

title: R-Ladies RTP: [ONLINE] #tidytuesday Work Group  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Join fellow R-Ladies in exploring a #tidytuesday data set! For those craving human connection and some practice flexing your data science skills, this is the event for you! We will hold our event via Zoom, where you can meet other R-ladies, improve your R skills, and build your data science portfolio. This event is for people at all levels of R (beginner through advanced).

This will be the second part of a multipart TidyTuesday event where we will be looking at a local (!) urban heat mapping dataset brought to us by collaborators at the Museum of Life and Science (https://www.lifeandscience.org/) and the State Climate Office of NC (https://climate.ncsu.edu/). These data were collected using PocketLab temperature sensors (https://www.thepocketlab.com/store/pocketlab-weather?hsLang=en) as folks walked around Durham and Raleigh this past summer (#walkingForScience). You can read hear more about this project in this WUNC feature here (https://www.wunc.org/race-demographics/2021-08-11/urban-heat-mapping-project-durham-race-policies-climate-google).

Agenda (all times in ET):
6:30 - 6:45 pm Meet & Greet
6:45 - 7:45 pm #tidytuesday
7:45 - 8:00 pm Discussion

What is #tidytuesday?
#TidyTuesday is a weekly social data project created by the R4DS online learning community that is focused on using tidyverse packages. A new data set and accompanying article featuring an interesting plot is released on Github every Monday. The goal is to generate a copy of the original plot or create your own original approach!

For more information on #tidytuesday, check out this blog post (https://bit.ly/2HqEsdt) and the main repository page (https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday).

Who is this for?
New and experienced R users alike! Let's learn together! All are welcome, including R-Ladies RTP members and R-Ladies from around the world.

What should I bring?
You'll need a computer with videoconferencing capabilities and R. Serve yourself a beverage and a snack to fuel your evening!

Where will it take place?
**Please join us online via Zoom.** A link to join will be provided when you RSVP.

All events are intended for women as leaders, mentors, members, and attendees. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly. Men are welcomed to attend *as guests* and must be accompanied by the R-Lady who invited them. This group was created so those who identify as women have a comfortable place to learn. If you would like to attend and feel excluded, please introduce yourself to an organizer.

description:
Abbiamo il piacere di annunciare un nuovo meetup in collaborazione con KNIME (knime.com).

Il (Virtual) Learnathon √® un evento a met√† tra un hackathon e un workshop: √® un workshop perch√© si studia il processo di data science. Ma √® anche un hackathon, perch√© si lavora in gruppi, attraverso esercizi, per mettere a punto la soluzione.

Durante il Learnathon sperimenteremo l‚Äôintero ciclo di un progetto di data science dall‚Äôaccesso ai dati fino al deployment, passando per un paio di algoritmi di Machine Learning.

Lo strumento che utilizzeremo √® KNIME Analytics Platform (https://www.knime.com/knime-analytics-platform).
KNIME Analytics Platform √® open ed offre anche un ambiente di sviluppo integrato per R, Python, SQL e Spark.

Dopo un‚Äôintroduzione iniziale ci divideremo in gruppi. Ciascun gruppo si focalizzer√† su uno dei tre aspetti del ciclo del progetto:

Gruppo 1: ETL. Focus sull‚Äôaccesso ai dati e sulla data preparation.
Gruppo 2: Machine Learning. Che modello dovrei usare? Con quali parametri?
Gruppo 3: Deployment. Dopo aver trovato un buon modello, cosa succede? Focus sulla fase di deployment.

Per via della situazione attuale non sar√† possibile incontrarsi di persona. In alternative, tutti potranno scaricare il materiale del workshop qui:
https://tinyurl.com/RLadies-KNIME-2021 (slides)
https://download.knime.org/evangelism/Learnathon/From_Raw_Data_To_Deployment.knar (workflows)

Forniremo ai partecipanti i data sets, i workflow per cominciare e le soluzioni degli esercizi.
Data scientists esperti saranno a disposizione per consigli e informazioni.

Per partecipare √® necessario portare il proprio laptop con KNIME Analytics Platform preinstallata e il materiale del workshop.

Per installare KNIME Analytics Platform (https://www.knime.com/downloads), seguite le istruzioni in questi video:
- Windows (https://youtu.be/yeHblDxakLk)
- Mac (https://youtu.be/1jvRWryJ220)
- Linux (https://youtu.be/wibggQYr4ZA)

Infine, se si desidera arrivare pi√π preparati sullo strumento, √® possibile seguire il corso gratuito in modalit√† e-learning: https://www.knime.com/knime-introductory-course

Dopo un‚Äôintroduzione su Zoom mostreremo come spostarci su Gather (https://gather.town/events/to14mt18JftdcgyYOt7M) per dividerci in gruppi e comunicare informalmente su una mappa interattiva. E‚Äô raccomandato usare Google Chrome una volta su Gather.

‚Ä¢ 18:00 : Presentazione di Benvenuto da parte delle R Ladies (Zoom)
‚Ä¢ 18:05 : Introduzione a KNIME Analytics Platform (Zoom)
‚Ä¢ 18:25 : Presentazione del workshop (Zoom)
‚Ä¢ 18:45 : Let‚Äôs work & learn! (Gather)
‚Ä¢ 19:45 : Networking e Fine Evento (Gather)

Il Learnathon √® un evento gratuito aperto a tutti.
Vi aspettiamo!

title: R-Ladies New York: End-of-Year Celebration for Women and Gender Minorities, United States, US/Canada
description:
[Please note: At the request of members of our community for an R-Ladies space exclusively for minority genders, this event is limited to those who identify as such (including but not limited to women, trans men, non-binary, and gender nonconforming individuals). Male allies have been great supporters of our chapter and the R-Ladies mission to promote gender diversity in the R Community -- for which we are grateful! -- and we believe the best way male allies can support us this month is by honoring the need for and benefit of such a space.]

Happy Holidays! To close out 2021, we are thrilled to host a virtual version of our annual end-of-year celebration and social! We'll utilize breakout rooms to allow participants to connect (or re-connect) with other members of our community in smaller groups.

*IMPORTANT* To RSVP for this event, you must complete and submit this Google form: https://forms.gle/3Rh6sukM2ngjfakM7
While you may RSVP via Meetup to let others know you plant to attend, Zoom link information will only be shared via email with those who register through the form.

Agenda:
7-7:10: Welcome and R-Ladies NYC Announcements
7:10-8:30: Breakout room chats (3-5 people, and we'll provide some topics to inspire conversation!)

title: Moffitt Cancer Center Bio-Data Club: Third Annual Bio-Data Club Hackathon  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Registration for the Bio-Data Club's Third Annual Hackathon is now open! You can register using this form: https://forms.gle/2ejXxdk4q8oT6XkJ6 . The hackathon will commence virtually on Thursday December 9th 2021 at 9am and conclude with virtual project presentations on December 10th at 3pm. The hackathon GitHub page (https://github.com/pstew/biodataclub/tree/master/meetings/2021-12_hackathon) has more information including descriptions of the projects and the tentative schedule. The list of projects for this year‚Äôs hackathon can be found here: https://github.com/pstew/biodataclub/blob/master/meetings/2021-12_hackathon/Project_descriptions.md .

A hackathon is an event in which participants come together to build a software product during a short period of time. Here is a short article describing what you can expect: https://www.rasmussen.edu/degrees/technology/blog/what-is-a-hackathon/. Last year‚Äôs hackathon (https://github.com/pstew/biodataclub/tree/master/meetings/2020-12_hackathon) featured 55 participants working collaboratively on 7 projects. Like last year, projects featured in this year's hackathon all have potential benefits for Moffitt.

This will be a fun event and we encourage everyone to sign up! The event will be very low stakes, and we encourage friendly competition between teams. Some programming background in any language is recommended but not required. If you are not confident in your programming skills, then there may be non-programming tasks such as finding validation datasets, cleaning data, creating figures, or creating slides for the results presentation that will still allow you to participate.

Please register by Monday, December 6th at 12pm or you may not be able to participate. We look forward to seeing you there!

The Bio-Data Club 2021 Hackathon Organizing Committee
(Anders Berglund, Rodrigo Carvajal, Jordan Creed, Guillermo Gonzalez-Calderon, Jose Laborde, Richie Reich, Paul Stewart)

title: Central Iowa R User Group: R and Python study group, United States, US/Canada
description:
Until we can meet again in person, please join our Slack workspace to stay in touch, ask questions, and share information throughout the week.

https://join.slack.com/t/centraliowarusergroup/shared_invite/zt-dhfa5ude-0tvHascxRkn2pgiqDdQgrw

The Slack workspace is available any time, not just Saturday mornings.

Are you tired of learning and playing with Python and R alone? Would you like to get together with a few friends and learn together? I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: Montreal R User Group: [Webinar] Automating Clinical Trial Master File Migration&Information Extraction  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register Here for Free: https://hubs.li/Q0114pgq0

Pharmaceutical Companies who conduct clinical trials, looking to get new treatments to market as quickly as possible, possess a high volume of documents. Millions of documents can be created as part of one trial and are stored in a document management system. In case migrating these documents to a new system is needed - for example, when a pharma company acquires the rights to a drug or trial - all these documents must often be read manually in order to classify them and extract metadata that is legally required and must be accurate. Traditionally, this migration is a long, complex, and labor-intensive process.

We present a solution based on the natural language processing (NLP) system which provides:

- Speed ‚Äì 80% reduction of manual labor and migration timeline, proven in major real-world projects
- State of the art accuracy ‚Äì based on Spark NLP for Healthcare, integrated in a human-in-the-loop solution
- End-to-end, secure and compliant solution ‚Äì Air-gap deployment, GxP and GAMP 5 validated

We will share lessons learned from an end-to-end migration process of the trial master file in Novartis.

Register Here for Free: https://hubs.li/Q0114pgq0

title: Montreal R User Group: What Can You Expect for ML in 2022  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Learn more and register here: https://info.datascience.salon/what-can-you-expect-for-ml-in-2022

As 2021 comes to a close, the challenges of productionizing and scaling team‚Äôs machine learning projects still remain at large. With all the big advancements in AI/ML, what are some actionable learnings for your team?

In this webinar join us as we talk about:

- Noteworthy highlights in the AI/ML space from 2021
- Upcoming trends in ML/AI for 2022
- Market movement (AIIA member valuations, acquisition and consolidation)
- The shift to ‚ÄòData Monitoring‚Äô from ‚ÄòModel monitoring‚Äô OR the evolution of ‚ÄòDataOps‚Äô - reference Andrew Ng
- Bedfellows for 2022: How hardware will meet ISV e.g. Nvidia/HPE and the AIIA ecosystem.
- Winners & Losers - Best of breed vs Production ML on ‚Äòso-called‚Äô E2E solutions. The new data providers and the role of analytics.

Learn more and register here: https://info.datascience.salon/what-can-you-expect-for-ml-in-2022

title: Montreal R User Group: DSS Hybrid: AI & ML in the Enterprise, Canada, US/Canada
description:
Learn More and Register Here: https://www.datascience.salon/ai-and-ml-in-the-enterprise/

Join DSS for our first hybrid event of 2022! We'll gather in-person in the famous Miami Design District and all sessions will be available for attending virtually as well!

The Data Science Salon is a unique vertical focused conference which grew into a diverse community of senior data science, machine learning and other technical specialists. We gather face-to-face and virtually to educate each other, illuminate best practices and innovate new solutions in a casual atmosphere.

DSS is the only industry conference that brings together specialists in data science fields to educate each other, illuminate best practices, and innovate new solutions in a casual atmosphere.

Learn from practitioners, technical experts and executives how to solve real-world problems by harnessing disruptions in data, artificial intelligence, machine learning, and cutting-edge technologies.

Learn More and Register Here: https://www.datascience.salon/ai-and-ml-in-the-enterprise/

title: Zurich R User Group: All around Shiny, Switzerland, Europe
description:
New year, new R meetup! We are looking forward to seeing you at our upcoming event!

Please read the details below.

#####

*Safety Concept for the Zurich R User Meetup @ UZH on 19 JAN 2022*
All Zurich R meetup attendees must bring a valid Covid vaccination certificate (= 2G) as well as an ID card. The event organizer will check this information for all meetup attendees. Moreover, all attendees and organizers must wear masks except for the speakers during the presentation.

#####

Schedule:
6.15 pm Doors open, checking Covid Certificates --> Entry is restricted to participants with a valid Covid vaccination certificate -- everyone must wear masks. [Please read above.]
6.30 pm Welcome Zurich RUG
6.40 pm Talks (see below)

~ 7:45 pm Are you hiring? Looking for an R related job? ... or organising an interesting event? Take the stage for one minute. (DM us if you need a slot!)
~ 8 - 9 pm Beer outside, location tbd

###

###
Speakers:

David Granjon (@divadnojnarg) - PhD Applied Mathematics - Sr. Expert Data Science @Novartis - @RinteRface founder and maintainer (https://rinterface.com)

Title: Outstanding User Interfaces with Shiny

Abstract:
In recent years, R users' understanding of Shiny has greatly increased but so have client expectations. While one of Shiny‚Äôs greatest strengths is that it allows producing web applications solely from R code, meeting client‚Äôs more delicate expectations will often involve going beyond R code and work with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. We recognize that R developers tend not to be familiar with the latter as they generally do not have significant background in web development, these may therefore appear daunting at first. In this talk, I‚Äôll present my journey toward the creation of the RinteRface organization, powering many Shiny extensions like bs4Dash or shinyMobile as well as the work in progress ‚ÄúOutstanding user interfaces with Shiny‚Äù book (https://divadnojnarg.github.io/outstanding-shiny-ui/), exposing some keys to design amazing user experiences.

###

Thomas Lo Russo -- Statistical Office of the Canton of Zurich, Data Scientist, Maintainer of the swissdd-package, https://www.tlorusso.ch

Title: Anomaly Detection on Vote Sundays with R & Shiny

title: CalgaryR: Validation of the underlying construct of survey instruments  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Please welcome our speaker, Cherri Zhang, Data Manager and Analyst, Department of Psychology, University of Calgary. We are meeting virtually on Wednesday, January 12, 2022, at 5:30 pm

Abstract

Background: Diagnosis and management of concussion depends on post-concussive symptom (PCS) ratings. One approach to validation of PCS rating scales is to examine their factor structure and to test measurement invariance (MI).

Purpose: To validate the underlying construct of survey instruments across raters, groups, and time using confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) and MI through the implementation of lavaan package in R.

Methods: Four models were implemented: correlated two- and three-factor models and bifactor models with two and three specific factors across four levels of MI. MI is a stepwise approach that compares nested models by adding increasingly stringent constraints to model parameters. The MI levels are configural, weak, strong, and strict. Models were compared using fit indices such as root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA), comparative fit index (CFI), and Tucker-Lewis index (TLI). MI is established when the fit of the more stringent model (e.g., strong invariance) is no worse compared to the one with more relaxed assumptions (e.g., weak invariance), as indicated by fit statistics. Additionally, OmegaH was used to assess the bifactor models to estimate the proportion of observed variance in total and subscale scores that could be attributed to the underlying factors.

Results: The bifactor models displayed better fit indices; however, model convergence took up to several hours with the three-factor model having convergence problems during initial CFA. The correlated models showed greater parsimony, shorter convergence time, and less convergence issues. Strong to strict invariance were established in all models.

Conclusion: The findings support a two-factor model of the Health Behaviour Inventory (HBI). The bifactor model showed the best fit, suggesting that ratings on the HBI also can be captured by a general factor. The results provide further validation of the HBI, supporting its use in childhood concussion research and clinical practice.

Please join us and learn together.

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: Your Laptop is More Capable than you Think: Large Data with {disk.frame}  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
Another in a series of talks about using R with data too big for RAM, we have ZJ Dai discussing {disk.frame}.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack: https://nyhackr.org/slack.html

About the Talk:
Every R user has run into the "cannot allocate vector of size xxxB." error at some point. For most applications, R needs to load the data in its entirety into RAM. However, RAM is a precious resource and often runs out.

The {disk.frame} package solves this issue by providing a framework to manipulate data on disk and minimize RAM usage. By using {disk.frame}, the user can perform analysis on much larger data than is ordinarily possible with R. A modern laptop with {disk.frame} can handle 100GB's of data.

About ZJ:
ZJ is a data scientist with over fourteen years of experience in the banking and tech start-up space. He is the lead developer of {disk.frame}.

The talk will begin at 7 PM America/New_York and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

title: R-Ladies Philly: 2022 Datathon Kickoff  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Do you want to practice your data skills while helping a good cause? Join R-Ladies Philly and DataPhilly for a 6-week datathon focused on exploring data for ElderNet, a local non-profit organization whose mission is to help elderly and disabled citizens maintain their independence at home. We will help them explore, stratify, and visualize their support services to ultimately tell a data story of ElderNet's impact in the Lower Merion and Narbeth region. We will be working on a deidentified subset of these data in order to:

- better understand the needs of our elderly and disabled population through data
- hone our data science skills
- learn and practice R, Python, and/or other languages you decide to use (there will be ways to contribute for people of all levels of experience with coding)
- get our hands dirty and our heads spinning with rich and messy real-world data
- work together, network, and make (new) friends in the data world!
- have fun nerding out together over data :)

The repository for the datathon can be found here: TBD

ElderNet: https://eldernetonline.org/about/

See you there!

title: R-Ladies Brisbane: R packages for data cleaning  [Virtual] , Australia, Australia
description:
*What are we going to learn?
About R packages used for data cleaning, such as naniar, janitor, stringr and robustHD.

*Who is going to present?
Simisani Ndaba from https://twitter.com/RLadiesGaborone
Simisani has a history of working in the higher education industry having been working at the Department of Computer Science at the University of Botswana as a Teaching Assistant since 2016. She graduated with her Masters of Science in Computer Information Systems where her research work was based on Information Retrieval in Authorship Identification using authors‚Äô writing styles PAN at CLEF. PAN is a series of scientific events and shared tasks on digital text forensics and stylometry. Prior to that, she worked as a Business Analyst at the Gauteng Department of Education working on data management and business intelligence in South Africa. She also holds a Bachelor‚Äôs degree in Business Information Systems and is due to complete a Post Graduate Diploma in Education, a teacher/trainer qualification in October 2021. She is part of the Ladies in R Botswana based in the University of Botswana and is an assistant in Health Informatics Africa.

title: R-Ladies Bucharest: R-Ladies #19 Build a new habit in 2022: Tidy Tuesday  [Virtual] , Romania, Europe
description:
Join us for a new session on the 25th of January, 7PM EET ! We continue our meetups with #goodRvibes and a challenge to engage in new habits.

Title: Build a new habit in 2022! Tidy Tuesday

#TidyTuesday is a weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem. An emphasis is placed on understanding how to summarize and arrange data to make meaningful charts with ggplot2, tidyr, dplyr, and other tools in the tidyverse ecosystem.

This meetup will be hands-on: after a brief introduction of #TidyTuesday and the weekly dataset, everyone will have a chance to explore the data and then share their work. Whether you want to practice exploratory visualization, apply a new analytical technique, try out a new plot theme or just learn tidyverse things from others, #TidyTuesday is for you.

To get a sense for #TidyTuesday ahead of time, check out the hashtag on Twitter, explore past datasets or check out David Robinson's screencasts below:

https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCeiiqmVK07qhY-wvg3IZiZQ
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Registration is free, but mandatory via meetup. We shall meet on zoom, and the link will be updated on the day of the event ( PIN for entrance should be sent by email ~2hours before meeting start).
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
CODE OF CONDUCT : https://rladies.org/code-of-conduct/
Please read our Code of Conduct before your first participation.

title: R-Ladies Baltimore: R-Ladies Baltimore and Washington DC -- Introduction to bookdown (Virtual)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
**Special co-hosted event!**

R-Ladies Baltimore (Bmore) and R-Ladies Washington DC are excited to co-host a meetup on Tuesday January 25, 2022 from 5-6:30pm (virtual meetup on Zoom). We will have an exciting presentation from Sam Tyner (@sctyner, https://sctyner.me), Data Scientist at Tritura, and a co-organizer of R-Ladies DC. She will be giving an introduction to the bookdown (https://bookdown.org) R package.

WHO is this for?
- If you are new to R and R Markdown & want to learn a cool thing you can do in R
- If you are a know R, but want to learn how write books and articles/reports with R Markdown

*If any/all of this is true, this event might be for you!*

AGENDA
5:00‚Äì5:15pm Who we are | Announcements | What's next
5:15‚Äì6 pm Presentation: Introduction to bookdown
6‚Äì6:30pm Networking -- Any more Qs?

Details on the location:
The Zoom information will be sent to those who RSVP the week before the event.

FAQ:
Q: Are men welcome to attend R-Ladies events?
A: Yes, men are welcome at this event. Our mission is to encourage more women and non-binary individuals to get involved in the R community. However, we ask that cis men come as guests of women and gender minorities to our events to promote a sense support and encouragement for women and gender minorities in the R community. Please help us by spreading the word about R-Ladies. Please also take the time to review our code of conduct before you attend: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

The term "women and gender minorities" is inclusive of individuals who identify as female (trans and cis), trans-men, non-binary, genderqueer, genderfluid, agender, intersex, and all minority genders).

Important to know:
- If this is your first R-Ladies event, please take a moment to review our R-Ladies Global code of conduct: https://github.com/rladies/starter-kit/wiki/Code-of-Conduct

title: R-Ladies St. Louis: Teach Me How to Google, United States, US/Canada
description:
Workshop description:

Googling for code help is something that all data scientists (at all career stages) do. But figuring out how to get the information you need back can be incredibly challenging, particularly for new coders. In this talk, we‚Äôll discuss strategies for refining your queries to increase your chances of finding informative solutions.
https://ucsb-meds.github.io/teach-me-how-to-google/#1

About the speaker:

Sam Csik (pronounced ‚Äúchick‚Äù) is the Data Training Coordinator at the National Center for Ecological Analysis & Synthesis (NCEAS) located at UC Santa Barbara, where she is working to develop and teach data science training curricula for the Master‚Äôs of Environmental Data Science (MEDS) program and other data science initiatives across NCEAS and UCSB. She is also co-organizer of R-Ladies Santa Barbara, a local data science group which works to promote diversity in the R community. In her spare time, you‚Äôll typically find her hiking with her pup or cooking family dinners with friends.

title: R-Ladies St. Louis: Creating Dynamic Reports from your Shiny App, United States, US/Canada
description:
Workshop description:

So, you've created your wonderful, interactive Shiny app. But now you'd like to provide your users with a custom report that they can download. In this workshop, we'll start with a basic ready-made Shiny app (no need to build/bring your own!) and go over several packages that you can use to create dynamic reports with reactive Shiny elements.

About the speaker:

Sonja Winter (she/her) is a postdoctoral fellow at the Missouri Prevention Science Institute (MPSI) at the University of Missouri. She has worked on multiple Shiny apps that are used as educational and research tools. Prior to joining the MPSI, Sonja completed her Ph.D. in Quantitative Psychology at the University of California, Merced. Her research focuses on using Bayesian methods to resolve data analysis challenges in psychology and education.
